raw_text:
US retail sales surge in December
 
 US retail sales ended the year on a high note with solid gains in December, boosted by strong car sales.
 
 Seasonally adjusted sales rose 1.2% in the month, compared to 0.1% a month earlier, boosted by a surge in shopping just before and after Christmas. Sales climbed 8% for the year, the best performance since an 8.5% rise in 1999, the Commerce Department added. The gains were led by a 4.3% jump in auto sales as dealers used enhanced offers to get cars out of showrooms. Dealers were forced to cut prices in December to maintain sales growth in a tough quarter when the usual end-of-year holiday sales boom was slow to get started.
 
 The increase in sales during December pushed total spending for the month to $349.4bn (£265.9bn). Sales for the year also broke through the $4 trillion mark for the first time - with annual sales coming in at $4.06 trillion However, if automotives are excluded from December's data, retail sales rose just 0.3% on the month. Home furnishings and furniture stores also performed well, rising 2.2%. But as well as hitting the shops, more US consumers were going online or using mail order for their purchases - with non-store retailers seeing sales rise by 1.9%. However, analysts said that the strong figures were unlikely to put the Federal Reserve Bank off its current policy of measured interest rate rises. "Consumers for now remain willing to spend freely, sustaining the US expansion. Given that attitude, the Fed remains likely to continue boosting the Fed funds rate at upcoming meetings," UBS economist Maury Harris told Reuters.
 
 Retail sales are seen as a major part of consumer spending - which in turn makes up two-thirds of economic output in the US. Consumer spending has been picking up in recent years after slumping during 2001 and 2002 as the country battled to recover from its first recession of the decade and the World Trade Centre attacks. During that time, sales grew a lacklustre 2.9% in 2001 and 2.5% a year later. Looking ahead, analysts now expect improvement in jobs growth to feed through to the High Street with consumer spending remaining strong. The belief comes despite the latest labor department report showing a surprise rise in unemployment. The number of Americans filing initial jobless claims jumped to 367,000, the highest rate since September. However, long-term claims slipped to their lowest level since 2001.
llama3.2:1b: US retail sales ended the year on a high note with solid gains in December boosted by strong car sales and Christmas shopping. Retail sales rose 8% for the year, the best performance since an 8.5% rise in 1999. Total spending in December was $349.4bn, breaking through the $4 trillion mark, but excluding automotives retail sales rose only 0.3%. Consumer spending remains strong and is expected to continue this trend as it accounts for two-thirds of US economic output.
llama3.2:3b: US retail sales surged in December with a 8% year-over-year gain, boosted by strong car sales and holiday shopping. Seasonally adjusted sales rose 1.2% compared to November's 0.1%. Total spending for the month reached $349.4bn, while home furnishings and furniture stores also performed well. However, analysts predict that these strong figures may not influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes, citing ongoing labor market uncertainties.
gemma2:2b: US retail sales surged in December, driven by strong car sales and fueled by shopping before and after Christmas. This contributed to an annual sales growth of 8%, exceeding expectations,  breaking the $4 trillion mark. While non-store retailers also saw increases, analysts expect this trend to continue with a possible impact on interest rate rises from the Federal Reserve.
qwen2.5:0.5b: US retail sales saw significant growth in December. Sales increased by 1.2% from a year earlier, led by a 4.3% jump in auto sales and 2.2% rise for home furnishings stores. Retail sales reached $4 trillion for the first time, up 0.3% from $4 billion last month. Analysts suggest that consumer spending is strong after previous periods of economic contraction.
qwen2.5:1.5b: US retail sales increased by solid 1.2% in December compared to November, boosted primarily by car sales and online purchases despite a slight decrease when excluding automobiles. Retail sales reached $4 trillion for the first time this year and are crucial for overall economic growth, with consumer spending accounting for two-thirds of output. The Federal Reserve's policy remains on hold based on current data indicating consumers continue to spend freely.
qwen2.5:3b: US retail sales surged significantly in December, driven by strong car sales and increased online purchases. Seasonally adjusted sales rose 1.2%, marking an 8% increase for the year, best since 1999. Auto sales accounted for much of this growth due to favorable dealer offers, while home furnishings also saw gains. Despite some weak sectors, total spending in December hit $349.4bn (£265.9bn), reaching over $4 trillion for the first time annually. Excluding autos, retail sales only rose 0.3% on a monthly basis. Analysts predict continued strong consumer spending and economic growth as job gains indicate an improving economy despite recent unemployment spike.

The increase was led by a 4.3% rise in auto sales as dealers used enhanced offers to get cars out of showrooms. Dealers were forced to cut prices in December to maintain sales growth in a tough quarter when the usual end-of-year holiday sales boom is slow to get started. However, if automotives are excluded from December's data, retail sales rose just 0.3% on the month. Home furnishings and furniture stores also performed well, rising 2.2%. But as well as hitting the shops, more US consumers were going online or using mail order for their purchases - with non-store retailers seeing sales rise by 1.9%. However, analysts said that the strong figures were unlikely to put the Federal Reserve Bank off its current policy of measured interest rate rises. deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about US retail sales. Let me read through it carefully.

First paragraph: Retail sales in December ended the year high with car sales strong. The seasonally adjusted sales rose by 1.2% compared to last month and jumped 8% for the year, better than previous highs from the late 90s. The increase was driven by auto sales up 4.3%, and dealers had to cut prices in a tough holiday shopping quarter.

Second paragraph: December sales pushed total spending to over $350 billion. Home furnishings also did well, up 2.2%. Non-store retailers saw modest growth of 1.9%. However, if we exclude car sales from December's data, retail sales were only up 0.3%, which is low for the year.

Third paragraph: Retail sales are a big part of consumer spending, contributing two-thirds to US economic output. During 2001 and 2002, sales dipped but rebounded in recent years. Analysts expect stronger job growth through consumer spending as jobs improve. Unemployment numbers haven't improved yet; there were 367,000 claims since September, the highest in 2019.

Now, I need to make a concise summary. Keep key points: December's strong sales, role of auto and home furnishings, employment trends, current Fed policy stance.
</think>

December saw robust retail sales growth with car sales leading the charge, driven by holiday shopping. Sales rose seasonally adjusted 1.2%, up 8% for the year, better than previous records. Auto sales surged 4.3% boosted by enhanced offers, and price cuts were necessary due to a challenging holiday season. Total spending from retail jumped $349 billion, while home furnishings and non-store retailers performed well with modest growth. Retail sales contribute two-thirds of US economic output. Unemployment remained high, but consumer spending shows signs of recovery. Analysts expect job growth through consumption as the Fed continues managing interest rates.
tinyllama:1.1b: The US retail sales grew by a significant amount in December, with seasonally adjusted sales reaching an all-time high of $4.06 trillion. This was helped by strong car sales and online or mail order purchases, as well as consumers' willingness to spend freely despite the economy's expansion. Analysts expect this positive performance to continue in the coming months, with consumer spending remaining strong despite lower-than-expected unemployment numbers and a rebounding job market.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
US retail sales ended the year on a strong note with solid gains in December, boosted by strong car sales. The Commerce Department reported that seasonally adjusted retail sales increased by 1.2% in December compared to the 0.1% increase recorded in November. This surge in sales was driven by a notable rise in auto sales. Shopping during the holiday season was particularly strong, with December sales rising 8% over the previous year's figures.

This boost in sales is attributed to an enhanced offer environment for consumers. Dealers slashed prices in order to maintain their market share in this tough quarter and attract shoppers. Analysts believe that these efforts helped increase sales by a record-breaking 4.3% in December, setting a new all-time peak in retail spending.

The increase in sales during December pushed total spending for the month to $349.4 billion - the highest figure recorded so far this year. Retail sales have surpassed the $4 trillion mark for the first time, and if automotive sales were excluded from the data, annual sales would break through the $5 trillion mark for the first time ever.

Despite an unexpected rise in unemployment claims earlier this month, analysts are expecting improved jobs growth to feed through to the High Street with consumer spending remaining strong. The belief comes despite a downward revision to initial jobless claims, which suggests that long-term claims may have reached their lowest level since 2001.
phi:2.7b: US retail sales surged in December with strong gains in car sales, led by enhanced offers from dealers. Total spending reached $349.4bn and annual sales topped $4 trillion for the first time, boosted by a pick up in consumer spending. Despite a slight drop-off in non-store retailers' sales, analysts believe that these figures support the Federal Reserve Bank's policy of measured interest rate rises. Retail sales are an important factor in US economic output as they make up two-thirds of consumer spending, which has been improving after slumping in 2001 and 2002.
orca-mini:3b: US retail sales surged in December, boosted by strong car sales and a surge in shopping just before and after Christmas. Sales climbed 8% for the year, the best performance since 1999, and were led by a 4.3% jump in auto sales as dealers used enhanced offers to get cars out of showrooms. However, if automotives are excluded from December's data, retail sales rose just 0.3% on the month. Home furnishings and furniture stores also performed well, rising 2.2%. Non-store retailers saw sales rise by 1.9%, but analysts said that the strong figures were unlikely to put the Federal Reserve Bank off its current policy of measured interest rate rises. "Consumers for now remain willing to spend freely, sustaining the US expansion," UBS economist Maury Harris told Reuters. Retail sales are seen as a major part of consumer spending, which in turn makes up two-thirds of economic output in the US. Consumer spending has been picking up in recent years after slumping during 2001 and 2002 as the country battled to recover from its first recession of the decade and the World Trade Centre attacks.
hermes3:3b: US retail sales increased by 1.2% in December, reaching an 8% yearly growth. Auto sales led increase; total annual spending reached $4.06trn.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: US retail sales experienced a surge in December, driven by strong car sales and an increase in shopping before and after Christmas. Sales climbed 1.2% for the month, with gains led by a 4.3% jump in auto sales due to enhanced offers from dealers. Total spending for the month reached $349.4bn, while annual sales broke through the $4 trillion mark for the first time. Despite some growth in non-store retailers and home furnishings and furniture stores, analysts believe that consumer spending will remain strong in the future, with improvement in jobs growth expected to support it. However, a surprising rise in unemployment claims suggests potential challenges ahead.
chatgpt-4o-latest: US retail sales surged in December, rising 1.2% from the previous month, driven by strong auto sales, which jumped 4.3% as dealers cut prices to boost demand. Annual sales grew 8%, the highest since 1999, reaching $4.06 trillion. Excluding autos, December sales rose just 0.3%. Home furnishings and online sales also performed well. Despite strong consumer spending, analysts expect the Federal Reserve to continue raising interest rates. Consumer spending, a key driver of the economy, has rebounded after slow growth in 2001-2002. While job growth is expected to support spending, unemployment claims unexpectedly rose to their highest level since September, though long-term claims hit their lowest since 2001.
stablelm2:1.6b: US retail sales grew by 1.2% in December, driven by strong car sales, reaching a total spending of $4.4 billion. The year saw an 8% increase in sales, the best performance since 1995. Auto sales contributed most to the growth, with prices cut in December to maintain sales momentum. Sales excluding autos rose 0.3%. Home furnishings and furniture stores also performed well. Non-store retailers increased sales by 1.9%. Analysts predict sustained consumer spending despite recent job market changes.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
US retail sales surged by 1.2% in December, marking a significant end to the year with gains largely driven by robust car sales. Annual retail sales reached $4.06 trillion, the highest in over two decades, aided by an 8% year-on-year increase. Auto sales saw a remarkable 4.3% boost due to dealers' discounted offers, marking a notable recovery from a sluggish start to the quarter. Non-store retailers also excelled, with a 1.9% rise in online and mail-order purchases. Total spending for December reached $349.4 billion (£265.9 billion), demonstrating strong consumer confidence and spending power.

Analysts anticipate that these robust retail figures, reflecting two-thirds of US economic output, will encourage continued job growth and bolster the High Street with consistent consumer spending. Despite a surprise increase in initial unemployment claims to 367,000 (the highest since September), long-term unemployment had its lowest levels since 2001. The Federal Reserve is likely to maintain its measured interest rate hikes due to the prevailing spending habits of consumers.
reference: US retail sales ended the year on a high note with solid gains in December, boosted by strong car sales.Sales for the year also broke through the $4 trillion mark for the first time - with annual sales coming in at $4.06 trillion However, if automotives are excluded from December's data, retail sales rose just 0.3% on the month.Retail sales are seen as a major part of consumer spending - which in turn makes up two-thirds of economic output in the US.During that time, sales grew a lacklustre 2.9% in 2001 and 2.5% a year later.But as well as hitting the shops, more US consumers were going online or using mail order for their purchases - with non-store retailers seeing sales rise by 1.9%.The increase in sales during December pushed total spending for the month to $349.4bn (£265.9bn).Dealers were forced to cut prices in December to maintain sales growth in a tough quarter when the usual end-of-year holiday sales boom was slow to get started.Sales climbed 8% for the year, the best performance since an 8.5% rise in 1999, the Commerce Department added.
